Award.AwardTitle: Acquisition of a Portable X-Ray Fluorescence Analyzer, and Upgrade of X-Ray Spectra Instrumentation for the Materials Characterization Laboratory CSUSB
Award.AbstractNarration:
0941106
Melchiorre

This grant supports upgrade of an existing energy dispersive spectrometer (EDS) mated to a scanning electron microscope (SEM) at California State University, San Bernardino (CSUSB). Improved capability for microspatial chemical analysis will support PI research and student research training including: 1) studies of the origin of placer gold deposits; 2) assessment of the distribution of lead and zinc impacted soils adjoining abandoned highways in California; 3) chemostratigraphy of volcanic deposits; and 4) archaeological artifact provenance. CSUSB is a Hispanic Serving Institution.

***

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project we repaired and upgraded the existing scanning electron microscope and elemental analysis instrumentation at California State University, San Bernardino (CSUSB). This work was successfully completed on time and the instrument is now available for students and faculty at CSUSB, and on a limited basis the other agencies and schools within our service area. This instrument permits detailed examination of samples through 1) scanning electron microscope to create images of materials up to 75,000 magnification 2) elemental analysis instrumentation to determine the exact elemental composition of materials, and to create maps of their distribution within a sample 3) as part of the elemental analysis instrumentation, a backscatter electron detector creates false-color maps of  lighter and heavier elements.

The first area of impact is the availability of this instrumentation to the community in our service area. CSUSB has a service area that is larger than many entire states, and encompasses many national parks, national forests, and other public lands. We have a constant parade of people who have found interesting geological materials and are seeking identification. While much of this work may be accomplished with visual inspection, this instrumentation has already proven invaluable in meteorite identification and evaluation of valuable mineral commodities. It has also been used within the first month of operation by a high school student who examined the purity and trace elements within particles of placer gold from a local river.

The second area of impact is the scientific community of CSUSB and other local institutions of higher education. This upgraded instrumentation has been used  by students as part of their course work and research projects, expanding their confidence and job skills by mastering the operation of a complex scientific instrument. The principal investigator (PI) has also used this instrumentation for research on lead minerals, with the results having been just published. The PI and his students are also actively working on the study of gold ores from several mines in California and Arizona. Future work planned, or in progress, includes examination of bone density in fossils, examination of volcanic deposits to determine eruptive cycles, and examination of archeological materials to determine possible origins of materials.
